title.narrative: 3.2 Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) SANITATION AND HYGIENE PRACTICES

description.narrative: Increased number people in rural, urban and peri-urban areas, small towns and at schools and health centres have access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene services and are empowered to end open defecation., which contributes to Children In Urban Settings / Local Governance, Sanitation. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2020, increased numbers of people, especially girls and women, socially excluded groups and others in vulnerable situations, are healthy and live in resilient communities, access affordable and equitable Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) services and abandon open defecation

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Increased number people in rural, urban and peri-urban areas, small towns and at schools and health centres have access to adequateand equitable sanitation and hygiene services and are empowered to end open defecation.

description.narrative: Sanitation and hygiene promotions, using Community-led Total Sanitation (CLTS) drives, the provision of sanitation facilities and hygiene promotions in institutions, reached 237,427 people. Latrines were also constructed and rehabilitated in communities, benefitting 97,547 people. As of the end of 2020 29,244 more people live in 53 open-defecation-free-certified communities.;;Community Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) was successful achieving 52% Open Defecation Free (ODF) zones on a target of 30%.;Compared to the baseline, achievements in both ODF and institutional sanitation surpassed targets for 2020. | Status:Partially met | As-of Date:31/12/2020
